tn.text: Translate this man's name as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:02:11|2:11]].

tn.ref: Dominion and fear are with him
tn.text: Here "him" refers to God. The abstract nouns "dominion" and "fear" can be stated as verbs. AT: "Dominion and fear are with God" or "God rules over all, and people should fear only him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: in his high places of heaven
Is there any end to the number of his armies?
tn.text: Bildad uses this question to express how great God is. The implicit answer is "no." This refers to the armies of God's angels. AT: "There is no end to the number of angels in his army." or "His armies are so big that no one can count them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Upon whom does his light not shine?
tn.text: Bildad uses this question to express that God gives light to every person. AT: "Nor is there anyone upon whom his light does not shine." or "God makes his light shine over everyone." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How then can man ... God? How can he who is born ... him?
tn.text: These two questions are used together to emphasize that it is impossible for a man to be good enough for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: How then can man be righteous with God?
tn.text: The implicit reaction is that he cannot. AT: "A man can never be righteous for God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How can he who is born ... acceptable to him?
tn.text: The implicit reaction is that he cannot. AT: "He who is born of a woman cannot be clean or acceptable to him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: he who is born of a woman
tn.text: This idiom includes everyone. AT: "any man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "See" here adds emphasis to what follows. AT: "Indeed"

tn.ref: the moon has no brightness to him
tn.text: The abstract noun "brightness" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "the moon is not bright enough for God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: the stars are not pure in his sight
tn.text: Here "pure" means "perfect." AT: "he does think even the stars are perfect"

tn.ref: How much less man ... a son of man, who is a worm
tn.text: These two lines say the same thing and are used together to emphasize that man is not perfect. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Bildad states that human beings as of as little value as worms. AT: "who is as worthless as a worm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is another way of referring to a man. AT: "a man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
